comment._content: It looks like the cable layer was a different Dacia. This one was a freighter built in 1900 and sunk by the Germans in November, 1915 after being sold as a prize to a French owner and renamed the Yser. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70715FE3E5C13738... Dacia's significance in 1915 was as a German ship, of the Hamburg-American line, which found itself in a Texas port at the outset of the war. Bought by an American, Edward N. Breitung, and its registry switched to the U.S., it was seized as a prize by the French on its next voyage for carrying freight bound for Germany. untreaty.un.org/cod/riaa/cases/vol_III/1861-1869.pdf see also: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70715FE3E5C13738... Here, it looks like they might have painted out "Hamburg" and replaced it with "Marquette, Mich" Breitung also bought the similarly ill-fated Seguranca:
